name: Cardiac Pacing
contents:
Cardiac Pacing

Surgeons put in Epicardium (ie, outside of heart - because they need to take off). 

Indications :

  1. Weaning off of CPB (because during CPB cardioplegic , ie asystolic) 
    • can take time to get back heart rhythm
    • RV pacing wires - to take off bypass - temporary indication
  2. AV nodal dysfunction 
    1. normally valve or open heart 
    2. AV (local to valves) fibrous skeleton - surrounding valves - aortic valve surgery in particular --> PPM (2%) 
      1. Direct physical damage 
      2. Oedema of AV node (may occur up to 72hrs after surgery) 
        1. Epicardial pacing is a bridge to recovery
  3. Prevention or treatment of secondary bradycardias in high risk patients 
    1. pre-existent AVN disease 
    2. surgeries with increased risk of bleeding/ischemia/surgical
    3. patients with complex co-morbities 
    4. -> Ventricular pacing system is required. 
  4. Optimisation of post-operative cardiac output 
    1. this requires use of an atrial pacing system (unless pt. has persistent AF) **arguably most important. 

Ventricular pacing can be acutely life-saving  -however if you have integretity of AV nodal conduction - then the patient can become hypotensive. 

1st Letter: Pacing, 2nd letter: Sensing, 3rd Letter: Effect (from sensed)

4 Outcomes of DDD Mode 

  1. Both leads inhibited/sensing only 'back up' normal sinus - no pacing spikes
  2. Pacing atria/sensing ventricles = rhythm is 'atrially paced' same as AAI
  3. Sensing atria/pacing ventricles = 'tracking the atrial rate' treating heart block ; same as VDD 
  4. Pacing both atria and ventricles 'AV sequential pacing' 2 pacing spikes

Pacing settings

  • Pacing capture - how much voltage required to pace
    • capture threshold - at what point does the pacing not produce a QRS -> then programme unit to x2-3 threshold 
    • Normal impedence (200-1500 ohms) - so I = V/R(impedence) so increasing voltage can overcome higher impedence caused by poor wires/system
    • Low capture <3V = good 
  • Sensing - sensing threshold is the amplitude of R wave 
    • so set VSense to be 1/3 of that so that it captures every R wave and therefore every asystole, but is higher than interference/artefact 
    • High R wave is better (stronger) eg 6mV giving Vsense of 2mV 
    • Having to set it lower would pick up interference.

name: Vasodilators
contents:
GLYCERYL TRINITRATE

Chemical: Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) is an organic nitrate

Uses: GTN is used in the treatment and prophylaxis of angina, LV failure associated with myocardial infarction and following cardiac surgery. It has alos been sued in the control of intra-operative blood pressure and for oesophageal spasm.

Presentation : prepared in the following formulations:

  • an aerosol spray delivering 400 micrograms per metered dose and tablets containing 300-600 micrograms, both used sublingually.
  • modified-release tablets containing 1-5mg for buccal admin are placed between the upper lip and gum and are used at a maximum dose of 5mg TDS while 2.6-10mg modified release tablets are to be swallowed and used at a maximum dose of 2.6-10mg
  • the transdermal patch prep release 5-15 mg/24hrs and should be re-sited at a different location on the chest.
  • IV injection - contains 1-5mg/ml (we used 1mg/1ml in Cardiac in Infusion containing 25mg/25ml) and should be diluted to a 0.01% (100micrograms/ml) solution before administration by an infusion pump and is used at 10-200micrograms/min). QA - also has a 10ml syringe with 100 micrograms/ml available. (check this)

(A)MOA: GTN vasodilates the veins by the production of Nitric oxide. This activates the enzyme guanylate cyclase leading to increased levels of Intracellular cyclic GMP. Although Ca2+ influx into vascular smooth muscle is inhibited, its uptake into smooth endoplasmic reticulum is enhanced so that cytoplasmic levels fall resulting in vasodilatation. **does cGMP inhibit Ca2+ influx**

Dose: Onset: R: S: E: T:

Effects:

Cardiovascular: GTN produces vasodilatation in the capacitance vessels, that is veins

name: Optics
question1: PULSE OXIMETRY: HOW DOES IT WORK? IS IT FAST OR SLOW AS A MONITOR OF OXYGEN SATURATION? WHAT PROBLEMS ARE ASSOCIATED WITH IT?
contents:
A probe is placed on the finger, toe, ear lobe or nose. 

  • Two light-emitting diodes produce beams at red and infrared frequencies (660 nm and 940 nm, respectively). 
  • There is a photo detector on the other side. 
  • The diodes flash at approximately 30 times per second. 
  • The diodes are switched on in sequence, with a pause with both diodes off. (This allows compensation for ambient light.)
  • The microprocessor analyses the changes in light absorption during the arterial pulsatile flow (AC) and ignores the non-pulsatile component of the signal (which results from the tissues and venous blood).
  • Pulsatile flow - The photo detector generates a voltage proportional to the transmitted light. 

The oxygen saturation is estimated by measuring the transmission of light through the pulsatile tissue bed.

This is based on the Beer-Lambert law:

Beer-Lambert law : This is a combination of two laws describing absorption of monochromatic light by a transparent substance through which it passes:

Beer's law: The Intensity of light received decreases exponentially as the concentration of the substance through which it travels increases.

A=ln(Io/I) (Io = Intensity of original light)

Lambertâ€™s law: the intensity of transmitted light decreases exponentially as the distance travelled through the substance increases. 

The microprocessor analyses both the DC (non-pulsatile) and AC (pulsatile) components at 660 nm and 940 nm. The absorption of oxyhaemoglobin and deoxyhaemoglobin at these two wavelengths is very different. Hence, these two wavelengths provide good sensitivity.

A = ε x l x C (where A is the Absorbance of the solution) epsilon is the molar absorption coefficient. it compensates for variance in concentration and the path-length to allow comparison between solutions.


Problems associated:

Poor perfusion, Movement artefact, electrical interference from diathermy, highly calloused skin, nail varnish, severe anaemia, cardiac arrhythmia, methaemoglobinaemia increased venous pulsation eg severe tricuspid regurg. IV admin of methylene blue dye.

The following can cause high readings : CO poisoning CO irreversibly binds to Hb. Cyanide poisoning = this is not inaccurate cyanide prevents O2 being utilised in respiration and so its extraction for the blood falls meaning saturations are high.
question2: LASERS : ACRONYM FOR:, DESCRIBE BASIC PRINCIPLES, FUNDAMENTAL COMPONENTS, DIFFERENT TYPES, HOW ARE LASERS CLASSIFIED, HAZARDS, PRECAUTIONS.
contents2:
Light amplification by the stimulated emission of radiation.

Principle :

  • Spontaneous emission : (electrons) spontaneous decay results in the emission of a photon with the same energy as the difference between the excited state and the ground state. (wavelength is inversely proportional to the energy difference between the two states).
  • Stimulated emission : (in this scenario electrons are already in their excited state) other photons in the vicinity of the atom can effect the atoms state. Specifically the atom will oscillate slightly as the photon passes, because the electrons are electrically charged and therefore respond to the photon, essentially an oscillating electric field. The oscillation encourages electrons to decay to the lower energy state - when an incident photon causes a decay the emitted photon is emitted at exactly the same time as the passing photon, the the photons are said to be in phase, and they travel away in the same direction --> ultimately (by the use of a partially reflective mirror on one side) causing a beam of monochromatic, collimated (a fine beam), coherent. :

Components:

  1. External energy source
  2. Laser medium
  3. Chamber containing laser medium
  4. System of mirrors - allowing amplification + partially reflective mirror to allow collimated beam to exit the system.
  5. Windows at each end of the deice are inclined to Brewster's angle (this is the angle of incidence at which light is perfectly transmitted with no reflection, thereby ensuring that 100% of the light is transmitted through the windows)
  6. Fibre-optic cable (to direct the laser beam)

Different types of lasers with their clinical applications:

  • Nd-YAG (neodymium-doped-yttrium aluminium garnet) lasers
  • crystal used as a lasing medium in solid state lasers, wavelength produced is 1064nm (near infrared)
  • good tissue penetration not absorbed by water
  • used typically for endoscopic surgery (reports of inadvertent pneumothoraces during ENT surgery due to these lasers penetrating and affecting tissues deeper than anticipated)
  • CO2 lasers
  • used as lasing medium in gas-state lasers
  • highest power laser currently available (also used in industry for cutting, welding and engraving)
  • wavelength of light produced is 10.6 micrometers (infrared)
  • poor tissue penetration as it is absorbed by water causing it to vaporise and destroy tissue contents. used typically for superfical surgery (eg dermabrasion and laser facelifts - unsuitable for endoscopic use.
  • Argon lasers
  • used as a lasing medium in gas-state lasers
  • wavelength of light produced is between 400-700nm (blue-green region of visible)
  • good penetration through transparent tissue (eg aqueous humour, vitreous humour and lens of the eye) maximally absorbed by red-pigmented tissues eg birthmarks, haemoglobin( used typically in eye surgery (eg retinal phototherapy and in dermatological procedures to cosmetically enhance pigmented lesions.

Wavelengths:

Gamma rays = <10pm = 1018 - 1021Hz

XR = 0.01 - 10nm = 1018 - 1021Hz

  • UV = 100nm - 400nm
  • Visible light = 400nm - 700nm
  • IR = 750nm - 1mm

Radio waves = 100mm - 10,000km

Classification

  • Class 1 - power does not exceed maximum permissible exposure for the eye
  • Class 2 - power up to 1mW and visible laser beams only, eye protected by blink reflex
  • Class 3 a - power up to 5mW and visible spectrum only but now laser beam must be expanded ( so that maximum irradiance does not exceed 25 W/m2) eyes protected by blini reflex
  • Class 3 b - power up to 0.5W and any wavelength; direct viewing hazardous eye protection essential
  • Class 4 - power > 0.5W and any wavelength; extremely hazardous and capable of igniting inflammable materials; eye protection essential.

Hazards:

Hazardous because they are high intensity and small area - so concentration. and transmitted in non-divergent beam (do not lose power with increasing distance from source)

  1. Environment - fire explosions, O2 and NO2 can be collected in drapes and get ignited if the laser beam is directed onto them
  2. Staff -
  3. Eyes - if the laser beam hits the retina a permanent blind spot can develop. (CO2 cannot penetrate cornea therefore cannot effect retina).
  4. Skin - if the laser beam hits the skin, a burning sensation is felt and this will trigger withdrawal
  5. Anaesthetised pt.
  6. Eyes - as above
  7. Skin - no self protecting withdrawal
  8. Airway fire - a real risk during laser surgery to upper airway. - Anaesthetic Emergency [LINK]

Precautions

  • General - designated laser protection supervisor
  • Equipment - eye protection googles, surgical equipment with matt or black finish to minimise reflection
  • Anaesthetic considerations for upper airway laser surgery -
  • Double cuffed, laser resistant endotracheal tube (often flexible stainless steel tubes with two cuffs to ensure a tracheal seal if the upper cuff is accidentally damaged by the laser.)
  • Cuffs filled with saline
  • Throat packed with wet swabs
  • O2 - air mix (as NO2 is more flammable)
  • Fi02 <25% if tolerated.

Airway fire: call for help, inform immediate theatre team, surgeon to switch off laser and flood site with water, remove ETT tube if feasible, ventilate with bag valve mask, continue with TIVA, refer to ITU
question3: EXPLAIN REFRACTION OF LIGHT AND CRITICAL ANGLE, SNELL'S LAW, FIBREOPTIC PRESSURE TRANSDUCER
contents3:
Swimming pools look shallower than they are - and a straw seems bent where it enters the water. All consequences of refraction.

Snell's law allows us to predict the path of beam of light travelling from one medium to another. n1sin10 = n2sin20

Transparent materials are characterised by their refractive index, which is the ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum to the speed of light in the material in question. In glass the speed of light is about 2/3 of speed of light in a vacuum therefore, refractive index = 1.5. (so 1 x 45 /1.5 = sin02) = sin-1(30) = ?28o

Now consider a ray of travelling upwards underwater towards the waters surface This time the ray leaves the sruface at a larger angle than the incident angle, ie, the ray is refracted away from the normal. If the ray has a small incident angle ie, it is travelling upwards at a steep angle it will escape into the air. If the incident angle is large, however, the ray will be reflected back of the lower surface of the water - phenomenon known as total internal reflection. This effect can be observed underwater whilst diving with a mask or goggles if you look at the surface of the water straight up you will see the sky but in the distance the waters surface looks like a mirror reflecting objects such as the seabed below.

Critical angle : when light is incident on a boundary between two materials at an angle greater than the critical angle it is internally reflected from the boundary rather than refracted out.

Optical fibres: made from extremely high purity silica glass, highly transparent. A data link converts data from analogue into digital pulses of infrared laser light. Another data link converts them back. Numerous medical uses - best known as light transmitter in endoscope.

Fibreoptic pressure transducer - used for measurement of intracranial pressure - basically a fibreoptic catheter with a reflective metal membrane on the end - Membrane is distorted by external pressure causing the reflected light intensity to vary, so that measuring the reflected intensity allows pressure to be calculated.

Fibreoptic endoscope / bronchoscope

contains an ordered (coherent) bundle of optical fibres - signals from the end of the scope are analogous to pixels on a screen and build up a picture of the image at the end. Bronchoscope has a channel for suction and can also carry surgical tools, such as biopsy forceps.
